Chris Coleman and Aaron Ramsey were among Wales' Euro 2016 heroes at the 'Don't Take Me Home' film premiere on Tuesday night. 
The documentary charts the Dragons' incredible journey to the semi-finals before they eventually bowed out to Portugal, reports Wales Online. 
Real Madrid superstar Gareth Bale was unable to make the screening ahead of the release of Merthyr-born Jonny Owen's film on March 3. 
Ramsey, Coleman, Ashley Williams and others were all snapped arriving at the premiere. (Photo: PA) Rio Ferdinand was also present (Photo: Getty Images Europe) 
Manchester United legend Rio Ferdinand was another guest, along with TV presenter Adrian Chiles and star of BBC One’s new drama The Replacement, actress Vicky McClure – partner of director Jonny Owen. 
Bale tweeted: "Loved reliving the incredible summer we had with Wales in this amazing film! Enjoy tonight boys!! # DontTakeMeHome # TogetherStronger." 
In the interview, Bale talks about the close bond between Welsh fans and players that was at the heart of the astonishing run. 
"To see the film, it did bring back all those great memories," he said. 
"It's a kind of underdog story and everyone loves an underdog. It just shows how passionate one nation can be and how together they can be and what you can achieve when everyone's pulling in the same direction. 
"The film itself brings together both sides of the story. 
"It really shows how we all connect. Us players, we're all Wales fans, we're the same as the fans. The film shows what amazing chemistry we have as a country." 
The film tells the story of a remarkable few weeks in France as Wales shook the footballing world. George Williams and Ella Palfrey (Photo: Getty Images Europe) Simon Church, Wayne Hennessey, Chris Gunter and Joe Ledley strike a pose (Photo: PA) 
As history unfolds on screen the film focuses on the players, manager and supporters who played their part in creating the greatest moments in Welsh football. 
Set against the music of 1960s French rock star Jacques Dutronc’s Le Responsable, it starts with the disappointments in Wales’ footballing past. 
For almost 60 years, Wales had tried and failed to qualify for a major football tournament. Having gone through the grief of previous manager Gary Speed’s tragic death, heavy defeats, and positioned as a tiny country team with no pedigree, all bets were off for how the underdogs would perform. James Collins and his wife Samantha stop for the cameras (Photo: Getty Images Europe) 
But, led by superstar Bale, the team quickly became the outside favourites, dazzling millions of football fans throughout the world. 
For those long-suffering Welsh football fans who witnessed it, it was the greatest story ever told.
